title: Breaking Bad movie: Who was Jesse’s letter addressed to in El Camino?
text:
Jesse here, checking to see if there any spoilers (Picture: Ben Rothstein/Netflix via AP)

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie is littered with reunions between some of the show’s best-loved characters.

But before we go on, here’s some fair warning: spoilers are posted below.

The Jesse Pinkman-led film finally arrived on Friday (11 October), telling the slow-burning tale of Pinkman’s quest for recovery, redemption and escape following the harrowing events of Breaking Bad’s 2013 finale.

Fans have been pouring over the 122 minutes of new BB footage over the weekend, with little Easter eggs and references to the original series being left here, there and everywhere.

As El Camino wraps up, Jesse is seen emerging from the back of a trailer in Alaska about to begin his new life.

El Camino really is full of surprises (Picture: Ben Rothstein/Netflix via AP)

As he pays his smuggler Ed – played by the late Robert Forster – for successfully getting him to Alaska, Jesse hands him a letter which serves as the only goodbye he wishes to make in his new life.

The addressee of the letter in question isn’t actually spoken aloud, but a quick cut to Ed’s hand at the end of the scene sees him holding a letter addressed to Brock Cantillo in Albuquerque.

Brock is of course the young son of Jesse’s former partner Andrea, who was brutally killed on her own doorstep by Todd in the penultimate-ever Breaking Bad episode as a horrified Jesse was forced to watch.

Jesse never got to make amends – or indeed contact Brock – after he escaped the Nazi compound where he was being held prisoner, but his affection for Brock evidently still runs very deep by the time of El Camino.

The original series didn’t work out very well from Brock: before losing his mother, he was poisoned by Walt in season four as part of a ruse to get Jesse to turn against his meth rival Gus.

Brock’s life was then placed in further danger when Jesse got kidnapped by the white supremacists, with the gang threatening to harm him and his mother (which they eventually did) if Jesse tried to flee.

Although Jesse clearly has Brock’s address committed to memory in order to send him the letter, it’s never actually explained where he might have gone to live following his mother’s death – nor does he make an appearance in El Camino.

We can only hope that Brock’s new home is somewhere that’s far enough removed from the possibility of getting caught up in the crossfire of another nasty drug war – he’s been through far too much already in his young life…
